titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI: Saturday. The Storm of rain continued all Night, and all this Morning until four or five this afternoon. Mr. Crawford called upon me to enquire if I had sent an answer to a question from Governor Bibb of the Alabama Territory, whether the Oath of Office could be administered to him by any other person than the President of the United States— I had received his Letter asking the question some days since, and by the President’s direction had immediately answered that he might take the Oath before any magistrate
competent to administer Oaths within the Territory. It was past twelve before I reached the Office— Taylor and Strong, came again upon their business. Taylor is willing to go back as agent to Petion’s Government, or to that of Christophe; or as Consul at Amsterdam, or any where to a place of honour and profit. Mr John Graham called likewise at the Office, and wished that the Congress Frigate might be ordered round to Annapolis to take the Commissioners to South America— I went to the Presidents at four, and had a multitude of objects upon which his directions were necessary. I left him about five— Cardelli dined with us. He has begun a new portrait of my wife; being dissatisfied with the first— I despatched a Letter and papers this Evening by the Mail to G. Blake at Boston.

2. V:45.Mr Crawford called to say that Christopher Hughes had written to him in great distress, owing to Mr Russell’s unexpected return to Stockholm as Minister whereby he, Hughes, loses his place as Charge d’Affaires. He is very desirous therefore of being appointed Chargé d’Affaires to the Netherlands when Mr Eustis comes home. I told Mr Crawford that I had recommended Mr Everett for that appointment, but possibly a mission to Berlin might make an opening for Mr Hughes. Mr Rush, Mr Gales and Mr M. Young called also on Morning visits; and I went with my wife and paid visits at Dr. Blake’s, Mr Bomfords, Mr W. Lee’s, Mr T. Munro’s and Mr N. Cutting’s. I walked home, calling first at Mr Fry’s, but they were gone out. My wife brought home with her, Mary Hellen her eldest Sister’s daughter, whom she takes to live with us. The present widow Hellen is very ill confined to her bed— All the leisure time of this day and Evening I was engaged in writing Letters to send by Mr Rush, and in bringing up arrears of Journal.

3. IV:30. Wrote Letters for Mr Rush. Visits at the Office from Barney, Consul at Trieste, and son of Commodore Barney, who is to be Commissioned as Naval Officer at Baltimore, and P. Bentalou as Marshal—from a Mr Leach of Boston, introduced by Mr Cutt’s, and who came to solicit the Consulate at Malaga, for a Mr Sprague, now at Gibraltar; from Mr Taylor, late Agent at Port au Prince, who came again to ask for the appointment of Agent at Cape Henry, and from Mr Crowninshield the Secretary of the Navy, who arrived here the day before yesterday. Between three and four O’Clock, I called with my budget of papers at the President’s but he was at dinner, I therefore came home— My wife spent the day and Evening at her Sister, Mrs Hellen’s, who continues ill in bed— Mary Hellen only dined with me, and after dinner I walked to Mrs Hellen’s where I found my wife. Mr and Mrs Boyd were also there, and Mrs Belt, a Sister of the late Mr Hellen— Mrs Hellen has a violent bilious fever and influenza. W. S. Smith has made some temporary arrangement with his Creditors at New-York, and returned here this day. His wife has been ever since he went away, and yet is, ill in bed. My wife walked home with me

4. VI:Mr Strong called upon me this Morning before breakfast, and said he had heard Mr Taylor would be sent out again as Agent at Port au Prince. He had no doubt Mr Taylor would if sent do for him the best in his power; but he was afraid Taylor was upon so bad terms with Petion, that he would rather injure than benefit his interest— That the general report at Port au Prince was that Taylor had been agent for some of the Privateers fitted out contrary to Law in the Ports of the United States, to cruize against Spanish vessels, with Commissions from the Insurgent South American Governments; and that this was the cause of his first quarrel with Petion— That at the time of the seizure and condemnation of Strong’s vessel and cargo, Taylor’s conduct had been harsh, and insulting to Petion and his Government, and when Taylor came away, Strong heard that Petion had said if he returned he should not be received. Strong mentioned several circumstances of rash and overbearing conduct on the part of Taylor, and said unless it should be absolutely necessary he wished Mr Taylor might not be informed of it; but if it should be necessary he would not flinch from his assertions— At the Office I had Mr Bagot, Rush, Barney jr. and Graham, upon various objects of business— Bagot came to say he was about despatching a Messenger to England, and wished to know if we were ready with the promised proposal relative to the fisheries. I said we were not; and told him Lord Castlereagh had promised me that a particular statement should be communicated to this Government, shewing the great
inconveniences suffered by the British in consequence of our fishermen frequenting their Coast, and shewing proof that it is not from any disposition to cavil or make disputes for trifles that they persist in pressing this object— Bagot said he had got the paper to which Lord Castlereagh alluded, and half promised that he would send it to me— I asked him if he intended to send me the note of which he had spoken the last time I saw him, about the affair of Captain Felix at New-Orleans; but he said he had been expecting to hear from me on the subject— His complaint would have been at most only of a want of courtesy; and ours was of a character so much more grave he should not think of addressing me first concerning it— Mr Rush and Mr Graham came upon affairs of preparation for their respective Missions— I met the President riding out on horseback as I was going to the Office. He appointed two O’Clock to see me— It was nearly three before I could get to his house; and I was with him till past four— My wife spent the day at her Sister Mrs Hellen’s, and came home with Mary Hellen, while I was at dinner— I purchased this morning a pair of Coach-horses from a Kentucky man— The President this day proposed to me to call on him every Morning, as I got to the Office; but said he would receive me, at all other times of the day, whenever I should call— I told him I seldom went to the Office till between eleven and twelve O’Clock, finding it impossible to do any writing there— He said he was fully aware of that; and I should find it a thousand times worse, when Congress should come to be in session, as the members would be continually calling upon me.

5. V:Mr Theodorick Bland of Baltimore, appointed by the President one of the Commissioners to go to S. America, called at the Office for Information— Mr Barney called for his father’s Commission as Naval Officer at Baltimore, but it had not been received from the President— Coll. Tayloe called to ask a Letter of Introduction for his son, to J. A. Smith— Young Tayloe goes out as private Secretary to Mr Rush, who has notified at the Department his wish to leave the City for Annapolis on Friday— Mr John Graham was again at the Office— We had company at dinner. Mr and Mrs Fry, W. S. Smith, Mr Bailey and Mr Purviance— Mr and Mrs Boyd were asked, but did not come, I know not why— Mr Robert Walsh, and Mr M. Young were engaged. Rush dined at the President’s, and Mr Brent was unwell— Our company was thus reduced to about half its intended number.

6. V: Called at the President’s as I was going to the Office. Barney’s and Bentalou’s Commissions by some accident got mislaid between the President’s house and the Office; and others were made out. Mr Bagot sent this morning a Note to my house requesting to see me. I appointed two O’Clock, at the Office, and he came. He said he had received a long memorial from several British Officers, committed for trial at Philadelphia, for violating the neutrality of the United States, by being engaged in a project of making war against Spain, on the part of the South American insurgents— He said these Officers some of whom were persons of distinction had, as British subjects applied for his interposition with the Government of the United States, who they supposed had power to afford them relief— He asked if the President had any such power while the judicial tribunal was in possession of the Cause— I told him that generally speaking the Executive in such cases could not interfere; but there might be Circumstances, in which they could— If he would write me a line on the subject I would lay it before the President and give him an answer— Coll. Tayloe called and introduced to me his son Ogle to whom I gave a letter of introduction to J. A. Smith— Mr Rush came home with me, and dined and spent the Evening with us.

7. V:30.Mr Pizarro, provisional Vice-Consul of Spain for the District of Columbia called this morning at my house, and delivered to me, despatches from Don Luis de Onis the Spanish Minister, and from G. W. Erving our Minister at Madrid, which were brought from Spain by Mr Noëli Onis’s Secretary whom he had sent home for Instructions. Erving’s despatches were very long and I had not time to read them through at home. I called at Pleasonton’s Office, and gave him some Letters which he had lost the day before yesterday from his pocket in the Street, & which my wife had found— At the President’s I found Mr Crawford who had business with him, and having mentioned that I had received the budget from Erving, by the President’s direction I read all the despatches relating to the Negotiation— Mr Crawford then went away; and I spoke to the President of the approaching arrival of Mr Greuhm the new Prussian Minister Resident and Consul General, and asked him, if he would now fix a time for receiving him, or wait until after his arrival— The President preferred waiting till after his arrival, and
said it was his desire to place the foreign Ministers here, much upon the same footing as the American Ministers were placed upon at the European Courts; upon a footing of form and ceremony. They had heretofore visited the President’s familiarly, and called to take tea at their houses as among individuals— He thought that improper. The intercourse between the Chief Magistrate and foreign Ministers should be reserved and formal. He had given them notice of this intention soon after he entered upon his Office. If they wished to ask for personal Audiences he would always grant them, and receive them in form— It was under Consideration whether he should have weekly Evening parties, as had been customary with the former President’s who had Ladies; if he did, the foreign Ministers as well as others might attend them: but otherwise, he did not expect a foreign Minister would come to his house without invitation— As soon as he should have a Secretary, he would also fix regular times for receiving visitors, for now he had not a moment of the day or the Night free from them— Even his dinner hours were molested. He had it also in contemplation that there should be a uniform dress adopted for the Heads of Department and Officers of Government; but that must be an affair of consultation— It was three O’Clock before I reached the Office, and of course I had very little time there— I came home just at the Dusk of Evening— My wife went with Miller the Carpenter, and looked over the house for which I am in Treaty with Davidson, to see if it can be made suitable for us to inhabit. She thinks it cannot.

8. V:Mr Frederic Greuhm arrived last Night with a Commission of Minster Resident and Consul General from the king of Prussia, and called upon me this Morning. Precisely at the same time came General Charles Lallemand whom W. Lee had yesterday asked to introduced to me; but which I had declined. He came this morning of his own accord; introduced himself, and asked to see me again to-morrow Morning to which I consented. I told Mr Greuhm that I would inform the President of his arrival, and take his orders for the time when he would give him an Audience to receive his credentials— I mentioned also to him two things which I requested him to make known to his Government, and which I had preferred speaking of to him informally, rather than to notice them by official Notes. His Credential Letter was addressed to the Congress of the United States. By our Constitution foreign Ministers were received by the President, and all Credential Letters from foreign Sovereigns should be addressed to him— He said this had occurred to himself, and he had made the remark when his Credential Letter was made out; but they told him they had only one record of a similar Letter from the King to this Government, and that was upon the occasion of my taking leave. They supposed that had been drawn up according to advice from me, and that was addressed to the Congress— I told him I remembered it well, but it had not been drawn up by my advice— I had received it as drawn up and delivered to me, without objection, because I was unwilling to make a difficulty at parting, and did not suppose it would operate as a precedent afterwards— He said he had no doubt his Government would readily conform to the regular mode of address when they should be acquainted with it. The other circumstance which I noticed was the union in his Commission of the characters of Consul General and of Minister Resident— A union so unusual in Europe that I had never known an example of it. There was this inconvenience in it, that as the Minister would be entitled to the privileges and immunities of the diplomatic character, and as the Consul General might be a merchant actually engaged in trade, there might arise very disagreeable questions of conflict between the claim of privilege and the rights of the tribunals of the Country; it was therefore the wish of the President that the Prussian Government should understand, that while we recognize in their full extent the privileges of public ministers we do not acknowledge them as in any manner belonging to Consuls— Mr Greuhm admitted the force of those observations; but said he thought there were examples of the union of the characters in Europe, though he did not personally know of any. He supposed however that his Commission had been adopted from the example of the Danish Minister and Consul Mr Pedersen— I had precisely suspected this to be the case— Greuhm added that there was a Mr Weiss coming with an appointment from the Austrian Government, writing the same characters— I told him that if he should
come, the same observations would be made to him— I called on my way to the Office at the President’s, and was there until 2 O’Clock. Mr Strong called upon me, and kept me there till between four and five renewing his charges against Mr Taylor, late Agent at Port au Prince. I dined at Mr Frye’s with my wife, she had been fishing all the morning at the river. Mr Frederic Frye was at his brother’s. I walked home after dinner. Mr Rush left the City this morning, and went to Annapolis, to embark with his family for England in the Franklin 74— Our German Servants Christine Neufer and Philip Scheiling arrived this Evening from Philadelphia.

9. V:General Lallemand called again this morning, and entered into a long explanation of his views and intentions, with a strong denial of his having ever contemplated engaging in any project contrary to the Laws of the United States. He said he had been invited to join in M’Gregor’s expedition to Amelia Island, but had declined— That he had refused to engage in some other projects of a similar nature; though he had an ardent love of Liberty, and a warm sympathy with the South-Americans whom he considers as struggling for that cause. He had never been the partizan of a man; but that of his Country. He had followed the Emperor (Napoleon) in his misfortunes, and of all his Counsellors, had alone advised him not to trust himself to the English— He added that if after these explanations he was still an object of uneasiness and suspicion to this Government, he would quit the Country and seek a refuge elsewhere, as he was determined at all Events to preserve his personal independence— I told him that he was in no wise an object of uneasiness to this Government— That they had received from various quarters information of a project for levying men, in the United states for an expedition to join the Mexican Insurgents; that Joseph Buonaparte was to be placed at the head of this movement, and that his Lallemand’s name had been implicated in it— That as this project was contrary to the Laws of the United States, which the Government were bound to see executed, its existence had given them uneasiness, particularly as its tendency was to force them to take a decisive part against the exiles from France who had sought and were enjoying an asylum in this Country— That the Government had now reason to believe this project was abandoned; there was no suspicion entertained against him and so long as he should conform his conduct to the Laws, the Government would neither have the power nor the inclination to molest him. He said he knew the French and Spanish Ministers were both much alarmed at the new projected French settlement on the Tombigbee, and the French Minister had sent to him Lallemand, a Garde du Corps of the king, to offer to enlist himself to go to Mexico— He said he had laughed in the Garde de Corp’s face; for it was really too absurd— I told him that his name had not been mentioned in any Communication from the French Minister to this Government— He said he had heard of some pretended Letters from Lakanol to the Comte de Survillier (Joseph Buonaparte) but he lived in perfect retirement and had refused to receive those Letters, which had been the only cause of their being intercepted. He, Lallemand did not know Lakanol; had never seen him; knew nothing whether he had written the Letters, whether they were forgeries, or what they were. But it would be hard if the Comte de Survillier should be held responsible for Letters written to him, which he had refused to receive— I wrote to the district Attorney at Philadelphia concerning the British Officers lately taken up there; sent for Mr Young who copied it and the paper to be enclosed with it, and they were despatched by the mail this day. I had visits from Dr Blake and his Son, from Mr R. Forrest, Mr Orr the Mayor of the City and others. I returned Mr Greuhm’s visit, at Tennison’s Hotel, and informed him that the President had fixed Tuesday at one O’Clock, to receive his credential Letter. He introduced to me Mr Sasse, his Secretary of Legation, who had two Letters for me, one from Mr Hellermann, a Dane; still about the Nicobar Islands; and the other from the Chevalier de Llaño, still importuning to come to this Country. Prolonging my walk before dinner, I called and saw Mr & Mrs Boyd. Employed the Evening chiefly in reading Newspapers.

10. V: Letter to my Son George. Mr Orr the Mayor called upon me again, and promised to have the road before my house repaired— When I came to the President’s I found Mr Crawford with him. General Lallemand and Mr Villers have been chosen Directors of the French Tombigbee Settlement, and now Lallemand, who is outlawed and under sentence of Death in France, has applied to be presented to the President. This led to some
discussion of the subject, and to a question how the intercourse between the President and the foreign ministers should in future be regulated— It was interrupted by a visit of Wyandot, Delaware, and Seneka Indians, whom the President received in form, but without the ceremony of smoking the Calumet which I witnessed on a similar occasion at President Washington’s at Philadelphia, in July 1794— Mr Graham, the acting Secretary at War, the President’s brother Mr Joseph Monroe, Coll. Wharton, and Mr Ringgold were present at the Meeting this day. There was a white interpreter for the Delaware and Wyandot Indians, but he did not understand the language of the Senekas, so that when they spoke, one of the Wyandot’s interpreted for them, to the white interpreter, who interpreted again to the President— They came to ask for some grant of lands, and some supplies: part of which the President assured them they should have, and for part, he referred them to Congress. They said they had all become cultivators of the land, and had altogether abandoned the life of huntsmen. Wine was served round; which one of them supposing it to be rum, at first declined taking. The President noticed his refusal, and expressed his satisfaction, at this marked aversion to ardent Spirits— After the Indians were gone, I was sometime with the President— It was three, before I reached the Office; and there I was engaged till near five— My wife went with Mary Hellen, and spent the Evening at Boyd’s.

11. IV: Deeply engaged all the morning, in writing Letters to go by Mr Rush. Mr. Taylor the late agent at Port au Prince called upon me at my house. He had seen Mr Strong this morning, who had told him his conversation with me. Taylor admitted that his house had acted as agents to two South-American privateers which had been fitted out at New-York, and were sold at Port au Prince; but he did not appear to be sensible that there had been an impropriety in this conduct— At one O’Clock I went to the President’s and found that Mr Greuhm was already there. The President soon afterwards came in, and Greuhm presented to him the Credential Letter, as Minister Resident and Consul General from the king of Prussia. The President received him standing and gave me the Letter of credence, without breaking the Seal. Greuhm made a short complimentary address to him, which he answered by assurances of the satisfaction, which he should take in cultivating friendship and harmony, with the Prussian Government— I accompanied Greuhm on his return to the door; and then left him returning to the President, with whom I remained transacting business about an hour— I then rode home; changed my dress and went to the Office; where I remained till five O’Clock, preparing despatches which are to go by young Tayloe to-morrow Morning, to Mr Rush— Mr Clay and Mr Robert Walsh spent an hour with me this Evening— Mr Clay was very animated upon South American Affairs.

12. VI: When I called at the President’s this Morning on my way to the Office, I found Mr Crowninshield there. Mr Crawford and Mr G. Graham successively came in, each upon business of his Office, and a general discussion ensued upon the projected expeditions to Amelia Island and Galvestown— I left it still unsettled having appointed to see Mr Bagot at my Office at one O’Clock. I found him already there at One O’Clock, and had conversation with him upon various points; but chiefly concerning Mr Stewart, formerly British Consul at New London, and now reappointed to that office, but whose conduct during the late war, was so exceptionable, that the President has hesitated whether he should now be received. He finally directed me to inform Mr Bagot that the exequatur should be granted; but merely with the view of conciliation towards the British Government; and that it should be put in the form of a written Communication in answering his application for the exequatur— After Bagot left me a Mr Mitchell Agent for Wade Hampton came to demand certain papers which he had delivered to the Yazoo land Commissioners, and which have been finally deposited at the Department of State. I told him I would look into the Law, and If I should find myself authorized to deliver the papers he should have them. I received three Letters from Mr Rush at Annapolis, about the difficulties into which he has fallen with regard to providing his Sea Stores— It was too late to go with them to the President’s, but Mr Brent took them to him after dinner. Mr Brent called at my house this Evening, and told me that Commodore Decatur had agreed to go to Annapolis to-morrow, and endeavour to settle the differences between Mr Rush, and the Captain of the ship, Ballard— And I am to write to Mr Rush by Decatur.

13. VI:Commodore Decatur called this morning at my house on his way to Annapolis, and I gave him my answer to Mr Rush’s Letters— He said the President had desired him to say that some allowance should be made to Mr Rush for the expence of his Sea Stores— I went to the President’s and suggested to him doubts with regard to the Law; and how far the Precedent might be extended. He then directed me to write to Mr Rush, that the allowance would be made if found compatible with the Law; and if not that application should be made for the sanction of the Legislature. He also gave me a confidential Letter from J. S. Skinner, Post Master at Baltimore, which he directed me to answer— He also directed me to revoke a Commission from the Department of State, issued by himself to a man named Jeremy Robinson, and to demand repayment from him of an advance made to him of 1000 dollars— He said the man had been very strongly recommended to him, but now appeared to be not trustworthy. I wrote the Letters accordingly. Wade Hampton’s Agent Mitchell came again for his papers but I found upon examination of the Law that I was not authorized to deliver them up, and declined giving them. Evening at home, writing— The weather has been these three days at summer-warmth— The thermometer in our Entry this day at 72— This Evening it grew cool— My wife passed the Evening in the small chamber.

14. VI:Mr Greuhm the Prussian Minister called this morning and mentioned that he had some trunks and boxes of baggage, arrived from London at Philadelphia; for which he wished an order to the Officers of the Customs to admit them duty free. I desired him to make out a minute of them in a written Note, and they should be admitted accordingly— He also gave me a packet addressed to London to be forwarded to Mr Rush; but I found at the Office it was too late; there being no Mail for Annapolis before next Monday Morning. At the President’s I found Mr Crowninshield, with the draft of Instructions for Captain Henley of the John Adams, to go and break up the marauding establishments of Amelia Island, and Galveston. I had drafted a Letter to Mr Erving, to give explanations to the Spanish Government on the said Subject— the Instructions and my draft were both read, & found to be entirely conformable to each other— Mr Crowninshield withdrew, and Mr Crawford came in with pressing business from the Treasury Department; upon which I took leave, reserving till to-morrow, the further objects that I have to submit— The President informed us that he had now given orders to receive the Heads of Departments at all times; but other visitors only at and after One O’Clock— Mr William Wirt of Virginia has accepted the Office of Attorney General, vacated by Mr Rush, and the Commission was this day made out; and sent to him— Mr Taylor called at the Office to ask if I had reported his explanations of his conduct, to the President. I had been obliged to postpone it until to-morrow— Evening at home, writing.

15. V:Mr Mitchel, W. Hampton’s Agent called yesterday at the Office, and told me that he had been to the President, who desired to have the papers that I had declined giving up, sent to him; and as he Mitchel had nothing but this business to detain him here, he would thank me if I would expedite the business as soon as I conveniently could. I told him that if the President desired the Papers they should be sent to him; but that there would be no occasion for him, Mitchel to wait here an hour longer on that account; as I apprehended it would make no difference in the answer that I had given him with regard to the Papers— This morning Mitchel sent me a note disclaiming with some affected form of respect the intention of appealing from my decision, to the President, but alluding in terms of importance and with some threatening indications, to W. Hampton’s Yazoo Claims. As I have no authority to enter upon any discussion of these, I thought it would be sufficient to give him that answer; but upon taking his Note to the President’s, he desired me to leave it with him, which I did. I found Mr Rodney and Mr John Graham with the President, and both anxious to embark upon their Mission to South-America, as soon as possible— I had taken a Copy of their former Instructions with me, to take the President’s directions upon the alterations and Additions to be made to them, which I did after they withdrew— I spoke to him of Taylor— He said he would read over the papers and give me a definitive answer respecting him on Monday— I read to him the Copy of the Letter I had written to J. S. Skinner at Baltimore. He suggested one alteration but the letter was already gone— At the Office I had several visitors— Mr Boothroyd, a solicitor for the appointment of Agent to Christophe, at Cape Henry; with Recommendations— A Mr Baptis Irvine of N. York, who brought Letters of Recommendation from Theodorus Bailey, Post Master at New-York, and from Genl. Saml. Smith at Baltimore— Irvine wishes to go upon any business to South-America; but I found him upon Conversation indifferently informed upon subjects relating to that Country. Taylor came again, and I told him that he should have his definitive answer on Monday— The President told me this day that Mr Calhoun had accepted the Appointment of Secretary at War, and would be shortly here— Among the Letters that I received this day was one of a singular character from the Buenos-Ayres and Chilian Agent Aguirre. In the Evening I wrote to A. H. Everett.

16. VI: Made a draft of Instructions to the Commissioners going to South-America, supplementary to those which they had received from Mr Rush in July. My wife went with Mary to St. John’s Church. I brought up the arrears of my Journal, and walked to the Navy-Yard. By the Mail, I received despatches from Mr Sumter at Rio de Janeiro. They relate to subjects of his former Correspondence with which I am unacquainted. This is one of the most laborious parts of my duty; to take up the threads of all the prior Correspondence, with our Ministers and Consuls abroad; as well as with the foreign Ministers here— Commodore Decatur was here this Evening, having returned from Annapolis, where he has settled the Affair respecting Mr Rush’s Sea-Stores— The difficulty arose as usual from a misunderstanding.

17. V:30. I received last Evening a Note from the President, mentioning that Mr Gales, one of the Editors of The National Intelligencer had called upon him to enquire if Mr Calhoun had accepted the Office of Secretary at War; and had been informed that he had— This morning I drafted and answer to Mr Bagot’s Letter concerning Stewart, and took it to the President’s— I called at Pleasonton’s Office and left Everett’s Account with him. I found C. A. Rodney with the President, and proposed reading the Draft of Instructions for the Commissioners to South America, while he was there. The President preferred that they should be read, also in presence of Mr John Graham, and asked Mr Rodney, to desire Mr Graham to call to-morrow for that purpose. Rodney went away. I read the draft of Instructions and left it with the President. He did not like the draft of a Letter to Bagot, and desired me to write another. On my reading Aguirre’s Letter to me, and his statement of his Conversation with Rush in July, the President desired me to send a copy of it immediately to Rush, and ask for his statement of the Conversation— I spoke about Ebeling’s Library— and what I had done to purchase it, with a view to give Congress the option of having it for their Library. He said that all books on the Geography of America became obsolete in ten years, and that 150 Volumes would comprize every thing worth having, concerning America. I met Mr B. Irvine at the President’s house, and he gave me two Letters of solicitation for Office; to go to South-America— Boothroyd and Taylor, both Applicants to go to Cape Henry Hayti were also at the Office, and are to come again to-morrow. Stormy weather— Evening at home writing Letters.

18. V:30. I made a second draft of a Letter to Mr Bagot, concerning Stewart which the President approved, and it was sent. Calling at the President’s as I went to the Office, I met there Mr Wirt the Attorney General— Mr Crawford afterwards came in. The President asked me to call again on my return from the Office home which I did— At the Office I had visitors, Mr Irvine, Mr Taylor and Mr Boothroyd— The President concludes to overlook Taylor’s past errors; as implying not absolute dishonesty, and because he is strongly recommended by Coll John Taylor of Caroline, and by Mr Madison— I had a new budget from Bagot, about British Mutineer Sailors at Boston— When I returned to the President’s he read over my draft of Instructions to the Com̃issioners for South-America, and directed alterations and additions which I accordingly made at home this Evening. The weather continued stormy till this Evening and then cleared off cold.

19. V:30. At the President’s— He approved the draft of the Instructions to the Commissioners for South America, and directed me to refer Mr Bagot’s Letter concerning the mutineers at Boston, and the papers concerning the affair of Captain Felix at New-Orleans to the Attorney General, which was done. Mr Taylor, Lieutenant Hall, and a Mr Bose were at the Office, on their respective concerns— Hall is a nephew of S. Ewing and brought me a Letter from him. I called at Mr Crowninshield’s Office, and delivered to him the Letter enclosed to me by Dr: Cook the Navy Chaplain— Crowninshield has no opinion of him, and has received bad reports concerning him, He promised however to answer his Letter. I received two Letters from Mr Rush at Annapolis— Cold weather, thermometer put out at a Northern chamber window, at 32 the freezing point this Evening. Hall wants a revision of the Sentence of a Court Martial against him— Bose is one of the Editors of the American Newspaper at Baltimore— The printing of the Laws was taken from them last Winter and given to the Patriot, another Newspaper. Now Bose wants it to be taken from the Patriot, and given back to them.

20. VI:30. The thermometer was this Morning at 34. and this Evening at 36. The day, clear Sunshine and warm— At the President’s I met Mr Meigs of the Land-Office with a map of the Army lands in the Illinois Territory. I received yesterday a Letter from the Chevalier Correa de Serra the Portuguese Minister asking in what manner he could pay his personal Respects to the President, and communicating the change of title of the Prince of Brazil. The President who has determined to have in future no familiar intercourse with the foreign Ministers, directed me to answer him that if he wished to communicate in person the change of title, of the Prince of Brazil, the President would fix a time for admitting him to a private Audience for that purpose; and simply adding an assurance of the President’s sensibility to his mark of personal respect. Mr Wirt the Attorney General called at the Office, and had some Conversation with me on the cases referred to him for his opinion. He asked for copies of the Papers; intending to keep an Official Record of all the Opinions that he shall give; which has not hitherto been the practice in the Attorney General’s Office— My time this Evening, was in some measure idled away.

21. VI:15. On calling at the President’s this morning with the draft that I had made of an answer to Mr Correa according to his directions yesterday, I found it did not exactly suit his ideas, and I was obliged to make an alteration of the draft. The President went again into the subject of the intercourse between him and the foreign Ministers, which he wishes to restore to the state in which it was under the Administrations of President Washington and my father, and which has been departed from in those of Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison; but in this retrograde movement he is anxious to avoid every thing that may run counter to the popular feeling, and every thing that may displease the foreign Ministers themselves. The case of Mr Correa is peculiarly embarrassing because his intimacy with Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison was great, and had existed before his appointment as Portuguese Minister. He has also been in considerable intimacy with Mr Monroe, who however now as President cannot discriminate between him and other foreign Ministers— W. Lee took me into the Apartments of the President’s house now furnishing, and shewed me the furniture lately imported from France— Mr John Graham and Mr Kemper were at the Office, Kemper has accounts to settle and finds difficulties with the accounting Officers— Mr Graham proposes that he and his brother Commissioners for South America should go and embark at Norfolk it being found inconvenient for the Congress Frigate to come and take them up at Annapolis. This Evening, I resumed the draft of the Report upon weights & Measures. Mr Brent gave some employment from the Office to J. Lathrop.

22. VI: I had written yesterday to the Portuguese Minister Mr Correa, requesting him to call at the Office of the Department of State at eleven O’Clock this Morning; but his residence being on the way to my office, I stopp’d there and he received. I met on the way Mr Greuhm, who gave me a list of the persons belonging to his Legation to be filed in the Department, conformably to Law— I received also last Evening from him a note with an extract from his instructions relating to commercial affairs— I asked the Abbe Correa, whether he wished for a private Audience from the President to announce the change in the title of the Prince of Brazil— He said no— But he had enquired of me in what manner he could pay his personal respects to the President, because he was aware that it should not be with the familiarity which would be proper between individuals— I told him he might call at the President’s house, and if not received leave a Card— He said he should in future leave a Card; but he had been apprehensive that would be too familiar a course; as it was customary in Europe for books to be kept in which persons wrote their names. I told him a card would answer here for the present, and if a book should be kept hereafter the foreign Ministers would have notice of it— The Abbe said that all these things were Officially necessary and proper, but he was sure my opinion as to the substance of all these things were the same as his own. I told him, I had no doubt it was— He asked me whether setting the Secretary of State and the Portuguese Minister aside he could sometimes come and see me as an individual— I told him I was at home every evening, and should be happy to see him whenever it should suit his convenience to come. He said he thanked me for the privilege which he would enjoy without abusing it— He then told me; but said he aid not ask it as a question, and did not expect I would answer it, but he had concluded from the Style &c. that I was the author of two pieces in the National Intelligencer, signed Phocion and a North American, in answer to Lautaro— These are all political speculations upon the question about acknowledging the Revolutionary South American Governments as I thought the Abbe was sounding rather unseasonably the ground, I thought it best to leave him in his
uncertainty, and simply said that when persons used fictitious signatures in the Newspapers, it was usually because they had motives for not signing their own. I took leave of the Abbe and left a Card for Mr Walsh with whom he resides; called at the President’s and made to him my daily Report. Mr Crawford came in while I was with him— At half past twelve I went to the Treasury and met him and Mr Wirt, as Commissioners of the sinking fund— After some Conversation and considering some Resolutions which he drew up, and sending for Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury and the Ledger, the Meeting was adjourned to next Wednesday at twelve O’Clock. I called at Mr Pleasonton’s concerning Kemper’s business, and was afterwards at my Office till near five— Evening idly wasted at home.

23. V: Began writing what I thought would be a very short Letter to A. H. Everett, but which proved a long one, and occupied me all the Morning— I then went out with Mrs Adams— Paid visits at the Comptroller Mr Anderson’s, and to his Sons— At Mr Forsyth’s, Mr Hagner’s, where we were received, and at Dr Tucker, the Treasurer’s. I left Cards for Mr Purviance, Mr and Miss Harrison and Lieutenant Hall. We called at Mr Frye’s from whence I walked home, and on the way looked in and saw Mrs Hellen who is recovering from her illness— I received a Letter from Mr Joseph Monroe the President’s brother declining the Office of a Clerk in the Department of State that I had offered him, as he has accepted that of the President’s private Secretary. Spent the Evening writing.

24. V: Fahrenheit’s thermometer this Morning was at 24. and the weather so cold that I could write scarcely any thing before Breakfast. Going to the Office, I stopped first at the Treasury Department, and left with Mr Anderson the Comptroller extracts from the despatches of the Department of State, relating to my accounts— At the President’s I met Mr John Rhea of Tennessee a Member of the House of Representatives. A Mr Baynard had been at the President’s with a Memorial from Mr McKim of Baltimore, owner of the Schooner Plattsburg, and the insurer’s, asking that a public ship may be sent for the Mutineers of that ship now in prison at Copenhagen— The President asked me to see Mr Crowninshield, and enquire if there was a public vessel that could be immediately spared for that purpose— Also to enquire of him if Commodore Lewis of New-York, was suitably qualified for the Appointment as Agent at Port au Prince— I saw Crowninshield, who thinks he is, and said he would ascertain whether there was a public vessel to be spared and would let me know. I shewed Mr Crowninshield also the paper addressed to Mr Graham, respecting the state and condition of the building in which our offices are kept— Crowninshield thought we should adopt some joint regulations— Baynard came to the Office, and I told him, if we could send a vessel to Copenhagen I would give notice of it by Letter to Mr McKim— Mr Bagot sent a note to ask an interview. I appointed two O’Clock this day and he came— He spoke of a Note that he had presented a year ago, about the duties on English rolled iron, and concerning which nothing was done at the last Session of Congress— Then of his Note about the Mutineers of the British Merchant Ship Sir Joseph Banks, brought to Boston in the Galen. Then of his Note, concerning the British Officers confined at Philadelphia. I told him that I should shortly send him an answer, upon this last case, with copy of the Report from the District Attorney, to whom the Memorial of the Officers had been referred— That the papers concerning the men brought to Boston, from the ship Sir Joseph Banks had been referred to the Attorney General whose Report I expected would soon be made, and I should then immediately answer the Note; but I thought we could not deliver up the man, and that our Law would in this case be precisely the same as the English Law. I added that if the British Consuls in this Country would attend a little to the Laws of their own, they would forbear many of their complaints, as in this case it would have been necessary to recur only to Magna Charta, and to the Habeas Corpus Act— Mr Bagot did not reply much to all this— He had in truth asked to see me for quite a different affair. Assuming suddenly a very grave air and tone, he said that the North west company had been informed, and he had been informed that the Corvette Ontario, had been despatched from New-York, on a Voyage round Cape Horn, for the purpose of disturbing
the British Settlement at the North-West Coast of America; and he therefore came to me to enquire if it was so— I told him I could answer him immediately that neither the Ontario, nor any other vessel of the United States had any orders to disturb any British settlement whatever. But he knew we had before the War, a settlement at the mouth of Columbia river which might be renewed, and that we had discovered the river— Our settlement he knew had been broken up by force during the War; after the Peace, the restoration of it had been demanded by a Note from the Secretary of State to Mr Baker, which he had answered by stating that no possession of the place had been taken by the British, but that they had immediately withdrawn after destroying the American Settlement— Bagot said Captain Cook had discovered the river, and that in 1787. Great Britain had spent upwards of three Millions Sterling upon a contest for that territory with Spain— for then they only had Spain to dispute with for it— And he thought G. Britain had some claim to the Country from the time of Drake’s voyage— I told him they had better claim from Sebastian Cabot, or Sir Walter Raleigh— He said no— That question was settled— Lieutenant Hall was likewise at the Office. Evening again cold.

25. V:15. About half an hour before Sunrise this Morning Fahrenheit’s Thermometer stood at 20, which was within two degrees as Cold, as it was at Ealing, through the whole course of the Last Winter. I found it impossible to write before breakfast— At the President’s, he informed me of his intention to propose in his Message to Congress at the Commencement of the Session the repeal of the internal taxes. At the Office we were much engaged in final preparations for despatching the Commissioners to South America. Mr J. Graham came and took leave— going to-morrow to Baltimore, and thence with his Colleagues immediately to Norfolk where the Congress frigate is waiting for them. Mr Roth the Secretary of the French Legation sent me two Letters from the Minister, who is detained at his place in New-Jersey, by the illness of his wife. I dined at Mr. Robert Brent’s— Messrs. Crawford, Clay, Bagot, Antrobus, Hughes, G. Graham, Walsh, Daniel & R. Brent junr. were there; and Mrs Pierson, daughter of Mr Robert Brent— We had much miscellaneous Conversation at table. Mr Bagot told me that he should write me a Note, about the Columbia River Affair; and should enquire at once quo jure— I told him perhaps we should answer by retorting quo jure he asked the question— He said he was sure he should express the strong feeling of his Government— I walked home in company the greater part of the way, with Mr Crawford and Mr Walsh— Mr and Mrs Frye dined with my wife.

26. VI: The weather moderated— I called at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office, and left with him my Observations, on my accounts that are to be settled. At Noon, attended at the Treasury for a Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund; but Mr Wirt the Attorney General did not attend, and the Meeting was postponed. While I was at the Treasury, Mr Clay came in with Mr Quarles and Mr Robertson two members of the new Congress from Kentucky. General Swift afterwards came in with Major Van der Venter who Mr Crawford told me was a Candidate for the Office of Chief Clerk of the War Department which Mr G. Graham is to leave— I had a visit at the Office from Mr Crowninshield, who says we cannot send a Corvette to Copenhagen until the Spring. General Mason likewise called at the Office to enquire from Mr Aguirre whether a passage could be granted to a person, a friend of his, in the Congress frigate, to Buenos Ayres— A similar application had been made last Summer when the Commission was to have been despatched— It was then made through Dr Thornton, by Mr Gual, the Agent from New-Grenada, and was then declined by Mr Rush— I therefore declined allowing it, on the ground of the precedent and that the Congress is not going directly to Buenos Ayres— General Mason said also that Aguirre had complained to him of having written to me, to ascertain whether I was of the same opinion as my predecessor; and not having received any answer. I told the General the reasons why I had not answered it, and probably should not; at least for the present. The President believed that Mr Aguirre’s statement of his conversation with Mr Rush was not perfectly correct, and I had sent a copy of it to Mr Rush, requesting a statement of the conversation according to his view of it. Mr Rush must have received my Letter after he had embarked, and I had not received his answer— This Evening I received Mr Bagot’s Letter; concerning the Settlement at Columbia river.

27. V:30. The President intended to have had a Cabinet Meeting this day to read his Message to Congress for the opening of the Session; but he was not quite prepared and postponed it. I had appointed twelve O’Clock to see Mr Roth the Secretary of the French Legation at which time he came. I had a short
conversation with him on the subjects of the two Letters that he had brought me from the Minister, and he said he should write to me again concerning one of them— I received a Note from Mr Crawford asking me to attend a Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund; and immediately went to his Office. We signed several Resolutions that he had drawn up. Returning to my Office I met Mr Newton the member of the house of Representatives from Norfolk, and two other Members just arrived, Mr Walker of North-Carolina, and Mr Silsbee of Massachusetts called also at the Office. Mr Silsbee brought me Letters from Mr W. Gray of Boston. Mr Deblois of Boston came this morning to my house, and mentioned his disappointment in failing to obtain the Office of Surveyor of the Port of Boston, which was held by his father in Law Mr Dalton, and which has now been given to Elbridge Gerry, son of the late Vice-President— My wife went this Evening to Incledon’s Concert, and took Mary Hellen with her— I received a Note from the President, requesting me to call at his house at one O’Clock to-morrow and to dine with him. I was therefore obliged to send an apology to Mr Walsh, with whom I had a prior engagement to dinner.

28. VI:30. MrWinslow Lewis came this morning to my house. He has a claim upon the Government by a petition to the House of Representatives, which by a Resolution of the House at the last Session was referred to the Secretary of State. He said it was referred not in the usual way to Report thereon, but generally, so that he had hoped I could finish the business without returning it to the House, but this I thought could not be done. He then asked me to make the Report as early as I conveniently could; so that it might be got through the house before the Committee of Claims should be much oppressed with business. I promised him that I would— I was only a few minutes at the Office, and at One O’Clock, attended at the President’s, at the Cabinet Meeting— He read his purposed Message, first through without interruption, and then by paragraphs. There was a variety of discussion, upon certain passages, and some alterations made. Messrs: Crawford, Crowninshield, Wirt, and G. Graham were present. Before the reading by paragraphs was finished, dinner was announced. At dinner, besides the Members of the Cabinet, there was Mr Joseph Monroe, now the President’s private Secretary, and Mr Purviance. I came home about seven, immediately after dinner, and walked with Mr Crawford. My wife with Mary Hellen, dined at Frye’s— The German girl, Christine Neufer, whom we had hired for two years and five Months, and for whom we had paid in advance, this Evening ran away.

29. VI:15. Upon calling this morning at the President’s with my daily budget of papers I found that he was gone out of town to Fort Washington; not to return until this Evening. I was occupied almost the whole morning in examining my Letters received at the Department, in relation to my Accounts, upon which a new question is started. Received a Note from the Spanish Minister, asking to see me, and an Audience of the President to deliver to him a Letter from the king of Spain. Received also a Letter from John Holmes; resigning his Office as Commissioner under the fourth Article of the Treaty of Ghent; with the Report of the Commissioners, declared at New-York last Monday. Antoine was gone all day in pursuit of Christine— but did not find her. This Evening Mr S. Herrick a member Elect from the State of Ohio to the House of Representatives, came and delivered to me a Letter to the President, resigning the Office of U. S. District Attorney for that State— It is said that a question is to be made whether these Gentlemen could be elected while holding Offices under the Executive Government.

30. VI:15. The weather has again much moderated, and this day was quite warm again. Mr Johnson, member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky called upon me, and recommended a Printer of the Laws in that State— Mr Carroll the young man who was with Mr Clay at Ghent was here. His father now resides in the State of New-York; and he has come to spend the Winter at Washington— Cardelli likewise came. He is now constantly engaged at work upon the Capitol— But he knows not whether he will be permanently employed— I walked an hour across the fields, to avoid meeting acquaintance and gazers, but met
Mr Walker the new Member of Congress from North-Carolina— Mrs Hellen dined with us. Mary went last Evening to her house.

Day.— I rise usually between five and six; and write till between nine and ten; when we breakfast. About eleven, and sometimes not until twelve I walk to the Office of the Department of State. Stopping at the President’s with the Letters and papers upon which I am to take his directions. I am usually with him an hour. Sometimes two; and thence proceed to the Office. There I am occupied till past four, examining and signing papers, reading Letters, and receiving visitors. I walk home, and seldom reach my house before five— We then dine after which from seven till ten I am writing, or reading the Newspapers. From ten to eleven is the hour for bed— I am already relaxing from my Industry.
